Title: Topographic organization of cortical inputs to the lateral nucleus of the macaque monkey amygdala: A retrograde tracing study
Abstract: The objective of this study was to identify cortical areas that project to the lateral nucleus of the macaque monkey amygdaloid complex. Discrete injections of the fluorescent retrograde tracers Fast blue and Diamidino yellow were placed into different locations within the lateral nucleus. Retrogradely labeled cells were mapped using a computer-aided digitizing system. In the frontal cortex, low numbers of retrogradely labeled cells were observed in medial and orbitofrontal regions (areas 10, 11, 12, 13, 13a, and 14). In the anterior cingulate cortex, low to moderate numbers of retrogradely labeled cells were located in areas 25, 24, and 32. In the insula, there were moderate to high numbers of retrogradely labeled cells in agranular and dysgranular regions. The parainsula cortex also demonstrated a moderate to high number of retrogradely labeled cells. In the temporal lobe, retrogradely labeled cells were most numerous in the rostral (polar) portion of the perirhinal cortex. Large numbers of labeled cells were also located throughout more caudal portions of the perirhinal regions as well as in the entorhinal cortex, area TE, and the superior temporal gyrus. Fewer retrogradely labeled cells were observed in the cortex along the dorsal bank of the superior temporal sulcus, in the parahippocampal cortex, and in area TEO. Although retrograde tracers can provide only limited evidence for topography, we nonetheless noted that the density of retrogradely labeled cells in a cortical area reliably depended on the location of the tracer injection in the lateral nucleus. "Our designation of area TE follows Bonin and Bailey (1947) with modifications by Suzuki and Amaral (1994). That is, area TE lies on the ventral surface of the brain, occupying the inferior and middle temporal gyri, and extends laterally to the fundus of the superior temporal sulcus. Suzuki and Amaral found the medial border of area TE to be somewhat more laterally placed in Macaca fascicularis than Bonin and Bailey described for Macaca mulatta. The border between areas TE and the caudally adjacent area TEO follows the electrophysiological findings of Boussaoud et al. (1991) and is placed at the rostral limit of the posterior middle temporal sulcus." (p. 55); "TEO+: area TEO plus more caudally placed visual association areas."( p. 53, list of abbreviations)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: It is only said that SA00 adopted the location of the border between areas TE and TEO. It should be noted that the other borders with neighbouring areas do not necessarily need to be the same.

"Bonin and Bailey's designation of area TA corresponds to the superior temporal gyrus. (p. 55)

"We have parcelled it into agranular (Ia), dysgranular (Id), and granular regions Ig; Jones and Burton, 1976). The ventrally adjacent parainsula cortex was identified according to Pandya and Sanides (1973) and Jones and Burton (1976), although, in agreement with Insausti et al. (1987), we observed that layer IV of the parainsula was weak rather than well-developed, as originally described." (p. 55)

"Our designation of area TE follows Bonin and Bailey (1947) with modifications by Suzuki and Amaral (1994). That is, area TE lies on the ventral surface of the brain, occupying the inferior and middle temporal gyri, and extends laterally to the fundus of the superior temporal sulcus. Suzuki and Amaral found the medial border of area TE to be somewhat more laterally placed in Macaca fascicularis than Bonin and Bailey described for Macaca mulatta. The border between areas TE and the caudally adjacent area TEO follows the electrophysiological findings of Boussaoud et al. (1991) and is placed at the rostral limit of the posterior middle temporal sulcus." (p. 55)
@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments: It is only said that SA00 adopted the location of the border between areas TE and TEO. It should be noted that the other borders with neighbouring areas do not necessarily need to be the same.

@Methods.Comments: Although it has been said that both fluorescent tracer substances Fast blue (FB) and Diamidino yellow (DY) were used for the injections, but it is not clearly stated which of the cases received FB or DY.

@Injections.Citation: "Thirty-five fluorescent tracer injections were deposited in the amygdaloid complex. Twenty-three of these included the lateral nucleus (Fig. 2), whereas the remainder of the injections were located in the other amygdaloid nuclei or outside of the amygdaloid complex. Although some of the lateral nucleus injections extended across nuclear borders (to the claustrum, external capsule, or the parvicellular division of the basal nucleus), the majority were confined to the lateral nucleus. Of these, three were located in the dorsal subdivision (M-10-92R, M13-92L, M29-92L), five were located in the dorsal intermediate subdivision (M7-92L, M8-92R, M12-92L, M28-92R, M30-92R), three were located in the ventral intermediate subdivision (M10-92L, M27-92L, M31-92R), and two were located in the ventral subdivision (M8-92L, M27-92R). In addition, four injections involved two subdivisions (Ld/Ldi, M29-92R; Ldi/Lvi, M12-92R; Ldi/Lv, M3-92L; Lvi/Lv, M4-93L). Figure 3 shows the locations of the fluorescent dye deposits for four experiments. In each experiment, the dye deposit was located in a different lateral nucleus subdivision (Fig. 3A, M13-92L, dorsal subdivision; Fig. 3B, M12-92L, dorsal intermediate subdivision; Fig. 3C, M10-92L, ventral intermediate subdivision; Fig. 3D, M8-92L, ventral subdivision). Figure 4A shows a fluorescence photomicrograph of the dye deposit for an additional experiment (M27-92R)." (pp. 55, 58).

@LabelledSites_Data.Comments: table 1 says that there were no labeled cells found in area TEO#, but figure 11B shows label in area TEO#

publication.title: Topographic organization of cortical inputs to the lateral nucleus of the macaque monkey amygdala: A retrograde tracing study
publication.abstract: The objective of this study was to identify cortical areas that project to the lateral nucleus of the macaque monkey amygdaloid complex. Discrete injections of the fluorescent retrograde tracers Fast blue and Diamidino yellow were placed into different locations within the lateral nucleus. Retrogradely labeled cells were mapped using a computer-aided digitizing system. In the frontal cortex, low numbers of retrogradely labeled cells were observed in medial and orbitofrontal regions (areas 10, 11, 12, 13, 13a, and 14). In the anterior cingulate cortex, low to moderate numbers of retrogradely labeled cells were located in areas 25, 24, and 32. In the insula, there were moderate to high numbers of retrogradely labeled cells in agranular and dysgranular regions. The parainsula cortex also demonstrated a moderate to high number of retrogradely labeled cells. In the temporal lobe, retrogradely labeled cells were most numerous in the rostral (polar) portion of the perirhinal cortex. Large numbers of labeled cells were also located throughout more caudal portions of the perirhinal regions as well as in the entorhinal cortex, area TE, and the superior temporal gyrus. Fewer retrogradely labeled cells were observed in the cortex along the dorsal bank of the superior temporal sulcus, in the parahippocampal cortex, and in area TEO. Although retrograde tracers can provide only limited evidence for topography, we nonetheless noted that the density of retrogradely labeled cells in a cortical area reliably depended on the location of the tracer injection in the lateral nucleus.
